data: Geothermal energy, one of the most abundant power sources on earth, now supplies 1% of the world’s energy and represents a key part of the global warming debate as an electricity source that could cut dependency on fossil fuels.
Unlike other alternative energy sources, geothermal energy is not dependent on reliable weather conditions, although the thermal source may itself disappear or degrade over time.
Tapping geothermal energy that is derived from the earth’s interior usually involves risky, mainly volcanic, locations.
As well as invasive drilling that is potentially harmful to the local environment, costs are over twice as high as drilling for oil.
Locating geothermal plants away from large population centres often means more expensive electricity transmission costs, although the “heat” that geothermal energy relies upon is available for free.
Parts of the Ancient Roman Empire used hot springs to heat their homes – and Iceland’s geothermal industry can still achieve such cost efficiency today.
The first official geothermal generator, at Italy’s Larderello dry steam field, was tested in 1904.
Governments have typically encouraged free trade during peacetime, whilst favouring protectionism during periods of war.
Import quotas and government levies are the two most prominent protectionist measures, the latter raising the price of imports to protect “cheaper” domestic goods.
Most of Britain’s protectionist measures were abandoned in the nineteenth century, but the political-economic climate of the early twentieth century partly reversed this.
Following the establishment of the General Agreement on Trade (GATT) in 1948 to promote the freedom of international trade, tariffs have now fallen to less than 10% of their post-war levels.
However, there has been some offset of this effect from the proliferation of regional trading blocs.
In today’s world the protection of domestic energy sources is a pragmatic foreign policy and can be viewed as an issue of national sovereignty.

The first duty of government may be to protect its own citizens, but there is also the need to recognise certain international obligations and to avoid slowing economic progress down by reducing competition.
In approximately 5 billion years’ time, the Earth is expected to be swallowed by an expanding Sun.
Thus, the long-term survival of the human race is reliant upon the colonisation of space.
The colonisation of the Moon is most frequently cited as the first milestone down this path.
Once humans have proved that they can cope with the Moon’s limited gravity, then the planet Mars would probably become the next destination of interest.
Humans have always loved to explore ever-distant lands, regardless of the risks and timescales involved.
The last manned trip to the Moon, in 1972, took a mere three days compared to Columbus’s considerable time in transit before reaching the New World.
Current economic constraints have however turned attention away from NASA’s Moonbase proposal for a permanent base on the Moon by the year 2024.
Many have questioned the practical benefits of such an expensive building, in which the majority of the astronaut crew’s time would be spent ensuring that they stay alive.
Any important research could be conducted in a much cheaper and safer manner using, for example, automated scientific probes.
The flow of ocean tides, as driven by the Moon and the Sun’s gravitational pulls, can be exploited by tidal power to generate electricity.
For example, placing a barrage system across a marginal marine basin with a high tidal range makes use of potential energy to power the turbines built into the barrage.
Alternatively, the technology of a tidal stream generator parallels a wind turbine’s ability to harness the kinetic energy of both incoming and outgoing energy tides.

Still, the tidal power debate has centred on the comparative environmental pros and cons of using this particular “green” energy option – not on establishing the most energy-efficient tidal power technology.
When compared to solar and wind power sources, the more predictable nature of tides and currents is certainly attractive.
However, two key concerns are the limited number of suitable areas for installing tidal energy plants; and that, comparatively speaking, relatively little energy is generated.
The government needs to determine whether there would be a sufficiently high return on investment to justify enhanced public sector funding for tidal power.
Approximately a third of all seafood consumption now comes from fish farms, with China being the world’s largest aquaculture producer.
There are both extensive and intensive forms of aquaculture.
The former, otherwise known as local photosynthetical production, uses a natural food supply – rather than an external supply.
Each type of aquaculture has its own different types of fish farm.
On land, fish can be farmed in tanks or ponds, whereas sea-based fish farms need to store the fish in wire cages.
Environmental groups have highlighted the dangers posed by the high levels of faecal matter left at sea, which can then spread diseases to wild fish.
Despite ongoing campaigning, little restriction has been placed by governments on the growing fish farming industry.

The evidence for economic benefits clearly outweighs that of any supposed health risk, which some protestors allege to be caused by all the chemicals that are used to artificially promote fish growth.
The trend of increasing working hours in Asia contrasts with the European Working Time directive of a statutory working week.

Does this directive intrude on a worker’s rights to determine their own labour, or is the intention to protect their freedom? A reduced working week may seem attractive as increased work pressures dictate longer working days.
However if you are setting-up your own business, then you may need to commit to a labour-intensive initial phase.

Then once you are self-employed, who is going to determine your working hours? Regardless of the directive being practically impossible to implement universally, a system of punishment for non-compliance needs to be established – ideally one that does not encourage the black market.
One argument in support of restricting hours is that it reduces unemployment.
However, this is a fallible argument; economic theory posits that this only encourages companies to drive wages down – not to hire more workers.
Also, those unrestricted economies would have a competitive advantage that could be used to leverage more investment internationally and encourage production to switch to their own shores.
Still, in France the 35-hour working week has been credited with contributing towards a workforce that is more productive than other unrestricted European countries.
Antarctica’s reserves of coal and iron ore are protected from mining by the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty.
Aside from this international agreement – in force since 1998 – the minerals would be difficult and expensive to extract from under the Antarctic’s 2.5km-thick ice sheet.
Sources that are cheaper to extract, which are also closer to world markets, are likely to be exploited first.
The Protocol also seeks to maintain the Antarctic as a “natural reserve, devoted to peace and science”.
Hence, environmental principles are included which aim to dictate all economic activities across the continent.
That said, in addition to academics pursuing scientific endeavours, there are tens of thousands of tourists who visit the Antarctic on board cruise ships.
Some of these visitors also engage in mountaineering and snow-boarding activities.
The Protocol also stipulates fish quotas, so as to avoid the overfishing that has occurred in other parts of the world.
Contrary to the calls for fishing to be made more limited in the Antarctic’s waters, some consider that illegal fishing activities there would be reduced if catch limits were raised.
The U.S. Presidential election process is based on an Electoral College, in which each state has its own set number of “electors”, based upon the state population.

Thus it is these “electors” that American citizens vote for – rather than voting directly for a Presidential candidate – who in practice then vote for their party’s “favoured” presidential and vice presidential candidates.
This process caused controversy in the 2000 US election when Al Gore won the popular vote, but George W. Bush was elected, having won most Electoral College votes.

The disproportionate role of swing states in determining such election outcomes is criticised, specifically whether the equality of each vote is threatened, and as a consequence questions are often raised about the democratic basis for the whole Electoral College voting system.

Since the USA is a federation of states, proponents of the status quo point to the need to take state interests into account and the way that the Electoral College system serves to protect the rights of smaller states.
Oil is a more financially viable and less dangerous source of electricity than geothermal power.
Cannot Say – the passage only refers to the cost of geothermal power drilling being “over twice as expensive as drilling for oil”.
There are economic pros and cons to increasing geothermal electricity supplies.
True – the passage refers to the free “heat” but the more expensive drilling and electricity transmission costs.
The first cost-effective use of geothermal power was in the twentieth century.
False – the Ancient Romans used hot springs to heat homes.
Geothermal plants are limited to locations away from large population centres.
Cannot Say – they are often found “away from large population centres”, however the passage does not specify that this is always the case.
Today geothermal power is only economically viable in Iceland.
Cannot Say – in Iceland hot springs are used to heat homes in an economically viable manner, however the passage does not state that this is the only country where this is possible.
Governments use trading blocs to improve the efficiency of world trade.
False – such protectionist measures undermine competition and according to the last sentence slow economic progress.
There have been fluctuations in protectionist measures during the twentieth century.
True – this can be inferred from the fourth sentence.
Regional trading blocs operate outside the GATT.
Cannot Say – the passage states that they act as a counter balance but not that countries cannot be part of both.
Wars and economic downturns often lead to more protectionist policies.
True – it states this in the first sentence.
Protectionist measures are sensible for essential supplies.

Cannot Say – the passage does refer to the “protection of domestic energy sources” as a “pragmatic foreign policy in the modern world” but it cannot be inferred that protectionist measures are sensible for essential supplies.
The most recent landing on the Moon was the 1972 Apollo mission.
Cannot Say – the passage refers to this as the “last manned trip”.
Travelling to the Moon is analogous to the exploration of new lands on Earth.
True – the passage provides the analogy of Columbus’s exploration of the New World.
The passage states that it would be safer for Moonbase astronauts to use scientific probes.
False - the passage states that the probes would be automated, but not that Moonbase astronauts would use them.
Astronauts would need to overcome the Moon’s zero gravity in order to survive.
False – the Moon has limited gravity.
Mars is seen as a likely target for the colonisation of space.
True – following colonisation of the Moon, “Mars would probably become the next destination of interest.”
There are financial and logistical concerns pertaining to further tidal power development.
True – there is a financial need to “determine whether there would be a sufficiently high return on investment”, as well as a “limited number of suitable areas for installing tidal energy plants”.
The Government funds tidal power research.
True – the passage refers to "enhanced public sector funding", implying that it already funds tidal power.
Tidal power is less susceptible to variable weather conditions than solar energy.
True – in the 5th sentence, it states that "when compared to solar and wind power sources, the more predictable nature of tides...".
Wind energy turbines can be used to generate tidal power.
False – the parallel drawn by the passage is with the incoming and outgoing nature of the energy tides.
Different tidal power technology harnesses potential and kinetic energy sources.
True – the passage describes a barrage system and a tidal stream generator as harnessing potential and kinetic energy sources respectively.
Environmentalist groups have campaigned for fish farming to be banned.
Cannot Say – the passage does not specify the forms of restriction advocated by environmentalist groups.
Sea-based fish farms keep the fish near the shoreline in mesh cages.
Cannot Say - the passage does not refer to the location of fish farms.
One of the dangers posed by fish farms is the spread of disease to other fish in the farm.
False – the passage refers to the danger posed by the spread of disease to other fish in the sea.
A minority of the world’s overall seafood consumption comes from fish farms.
True – the passage states the approximate level to be a third.
Location is the key differentiator between different types of fish farm.
The text makes no explicit reference to a key differentiator between the types of fish farms.
The European Working Time directive will reduce unemployment.
Cannot Say – the passage does mention this as one of the supporting arguments, but not as a fact.
The European Working Time directive would not apply to the self-employed.
Cannot Say – the passage only highlights the difficulties of enforcing the directive on the self-employed.
The working time directive would be impossible to implement globally.
True – the passage states “Regardless of the directive being practically impossible to implement universally”.
The passage supports the European Working Time directive.
False – whilst the passage presents both sides of the debate, overall it questions the merits of the European Working Time directive.
The length of the working day is increasing for the typical Asian worker.
True – the passage refers to the trend towards longer working hours in Asia.
The Antarctic’s mineral resources would be relatively expensive to transport to users.
True – the passage refers to the “Cheaper sources to extract, which are also closer to world markets”.
The Antarctic is protected by international Treaty from both mining and environmental exploitation.
True – paraphrases the second and fourth sentences.
Antarctic tourists do not set foot on the ice.
False – the passage states that they engage in “mountaineering and snow-boarding activities.”
All economic activity in Antarctica is banned by the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty.
False – the passage notes the large number of tourists who visit the Antarctic.
Low fishing quotas for the Antarctic encourages illegal fishing.
Cannot Say – there are fishing quotas set by the Protocol, although “only some consider that illegal fishing activities would be reduced if catch limits were raised”.
George W. Bush won more states than Al Gore in the 2000 U.S. election.
Cannot Say – the passage states that George W. Bush won more Electoral College votes, but it is not specified whether he won more states.
U.S. citizens vote indirectly for their preferred Presidential candidate.
True – this can be inferred from the second and third sentences.
A majority of the popular vote is needed to win a U.S. Presidential Election.
False – the passage states that Al Gore won the popular vote, but George W. Bush was elected.
The role of swing states played a critical role in the 2000 U.S. election.
True – this can be inferred from sentences four and five.
The Electoral College system is biased towards some U.S. states.
True – the passage states that “the Electoral College system serves to protect the rights of smaller states”.
